Had to go and some a bit of goog digging to see if I could stream that doc somewhere to see the mentioned 100 footer. Although, I'm still looking for a decent link, I did come across a good article from 2003 detailing the Odyssey's mission, and both [Cortez and Jaws were mentioned.](http://www.si.com/vault/2003/03/17/339758/the-chase-is-on-for-the-hundred-foot-wave-the-billabong-odyssey-has-the-worlds-top-surfers-gunning-for-the-really-big-one)
Nazare, Portugal seems to have some pretty gnarly waves too. Gonna go back and googs some more; this kinda shit fascinates me
E: Apparently Mike Parsons was the one that rode that big one at Jaws in the Odyssey doc and it was a [64 ft wave.](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=IsHzU0ynRZk) So not 100 ft, but still fucking huge. Before the Odyssey, however, he rode a 66 footer at Cortez, which he got the world record for. Then he broke that record in 2008 with a 77 footer again at Cortez.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mike_Parsons_%28surfer%29
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cortes_Bank
http://www.bbc.co.uk/wales/surfing/sites/features/pages/billabong_odyssey.shtml
Garrett McNamara has the current *Guinness* record of 78 ft surfed at Nazare, Portugal (I italicized Guiness, cuz it looks like there could be dispute over the tallest wave ever ridden, but Guinness seems to be the most "official" documentation). Garrett also has claims to have ridden a 100 footer also in Navare.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Garrett_McNamara
Benjamin Sanchis has also ridden a wave that many believe to be at least 100 ft.
http://www.theinertia.com/surf/did-benjamin-sanchis-finally-break-the-100-foot-wave-barrier-2/#modal-close
I'm sure there are others claiming the "big one", but I'm getting hungry. I didn't realize how much homework looking this up would be haha. Feel free to expand.

The standard grip amongst us kitchen dreggs with a chefs knife is probably the grip shown in the right-most picture; i.e. the "pinch grip". It provides the most stability/control and prevents the blade from twisting while you are cutting. For example, the potential of the handle becoming a bit slippery when cutting is a pretty common occurrence in the kitchen. And the potential for the blade rolling or twisting in your hand is much higher with the first two grips vs. the pinch grip which pretty much eliminates this possibility regardless if the handle gets slick or not. The choke up and the pinch of the blade prevents any kind of roll out and/or possibility of bleeding all over someones dinner.
I do find the middle photo, with the index finger splayed over the spine of the knife, to be somewhat useful/comfortable when butchering/cleaning proteins, though.
I guess it's really whatever floats your fancy and is most comfortable to you when you use a knife. But, for me, one of the first things I notice about a cook is how they hold a knife. It says a lot.

Although, I really would probably disagree with just about anything she had to say from a political (maybe any) standpoint, I really can't fault solely her for thinking this way. People are molded by their upbringings: family, friends, localized society. It's pretty easy to get lost in that sort of dissonance when you never have anybody within your "circle" to encourage you to look outside the box. And you know what? Why the fuck would I want someone that counter thinks things a part of my circle, anyways?
Maybe, perhaps, for growth/maturity/wisdom? And, I know that that is the answer. But, I aint gonna lie, it's hard to break that mold. I know. I struggle with this *all* the time.

I getcha. Now having watched this version. And not liking to do things half-assed, I feel like I have to watch that version, along with reading the book as well

So, I just finished watching the rest of it and it was really good. But, it is quite a bit different than Soderbergh's version. Neither in a bad or good way. Just different.
Having not read the book, I feel like Tarkovsky's version may be more closely aligned to the book and Soderbergh may have taken a little more directorial privilege in his adaptation. There seemed to be more story in T's. Like on an *existential* level. I mean that was there too, in S' version, but the idea of intimate love, in his, seemed to predicate the former.
Camerawork, composition were beautiful in T's. And the screenplay and script were also on point.
Like I said, I think they are both good; just *different*. I'll definitely have to watch T's a few more times to try and understand it better for sure. All in all, I think you would really like it. Fyi: It is pushing on 3hrs, though. Which I don't mind, but it is the reason I had to take a sleep break, in-between
Oh yeah, I forgot about that one too. That one was a made for TV version, if I remember right
